questions.text: A and B in the graph below are representative of which of the following ions, in terms of permeability for action potential generation?
questions.solution:
• During the early portion of the action potential, the ratio of sodium to potassium conductance increases more than 1000-fold.
  • So more sodium ions flow to the interior of the fiber than potassium ions to the exterior which causes membrane potential to become positive at the action potential onset.
  • After that the sodium channels begin to close and the potassium channels begin to open so the ratio of conductance shifts in favour of high potassium conductance but low sodium conductance which allows a very rapid loss of potassium ions to the exterior but virtually zero flow of sodium ions to the interior.
  • Ultimately the action potential quickly returns to its baseline level.

questions.text: Which of the following happens in response to heat acclimation
questions.solution:
• In response to heat acclimatization (acclimation) there will be an increase in sweating.
  • There is change in the internal sweat gland cells to increase their sweating capability.
  • When a person is exposed to hot weather for 1 to 6 weeks, he or she begins to sweat more profusely, often increasing maximum sweat production to as much as 2 to 3 L/hr.
  • Evaporation of this much sweat can remove heat from the body at a rate more than 10 times the normal basal rate of heat production.
  • Also there will be decrease in the concentration of sodium chloride in the sweat, which allows progressively better conservation of body salt which is caused by increased secretion of aldosterone by the adrenocortical glands which results from a slight decrease in sodium chloride concentration in the extracellular fluid and plasma.

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma:
questions.solution:
Thyroid binding prealbumin which is also known as transthyretin is a carrier protein for thyroid hormone in the bloodstream.

Albumin is a carrier protein and an osmotic regulator which carries hormones, amino acids, steroids, vitamins and fatty acids.

Haptoglobin is responsible for transport of cell-free haemoglobin.

Hemopexin binds to porphyrins particularly to heme for heme recycling.

questions.text: Which physiological adaptation does not happen at high altitudes?
questions.solution:
Respiratory Acidosis does not occur at high altitude. At high altitude there is hyperventilation which leads to decrease in the PaCO2 and increase in pH which results in Respiratory alkalosis which leads to altitude sickness (headache, sleep disturbances, nausea, fatigue, lightheadedness).

Other options:

Option A: Chronic hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction occurs due to lack of smooth muscles in pulmonary arteries leading to increase in pulmonary vascular resistance resulting in hypertension, right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH).

Option B: At high altitude the total barometric pressure decreases so atmospheric oxygen decreases so there is decrease in PaO2 leading to hypoxic hypoxia.

Option C: At high altitude there is increased secretion of erythropoietin resulting in polycythemia (abnormal increase in RBC count).

questions.text: TENS is used to relieve pain. What is the mechanism behind it?
questions.solution:
• Gate control theory is the mechanism behind Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS).
  • This method uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers in the vicinity of the injury.
  • The relief is due to activation of innocuous cutaneous mechanoreceptors whose afferents emit collaterals that terminate in the dorsal horn.
  • The activity of these cutaneous mechanosensitive afferents reduce the responsiveness of dorsal horn neurons to their input from nociceptive afferent terminals.
  • This is called the gate-control mechanism of pain modulation.

questions.text: In the following diagram, the curve "X" represents the normal relationship of alveolar ventilation with PaCO2, when PaO2 is 100 mm Hg. If pH changed from 7.4 to 7.3, change in alveolar ventilation will shift to which of the curve?
questions.solution:
• If pH changed from 7.4 to 7.3, change in alveolar ventilation shifted to Curve C.
  • The red curves were measured at a blood pH of 7.4 and the green curves were measured at a pH of 7.3.
  • We now have two families of curves representing the combined effects of PCO2 and PO2 on ventilation at two different pH values.
  • The curve would be displaced to the right at higher pH and displaced to the left at lower pH.
  • Therefore, using this diagram, one can predict the level of alveolar ventilation for most combinations of alveolar PCO2, alveolar PO2 and arterial pH.

questions.text: Counter current mechanism is present in which of the following parts of the body, except?
questions.solution:
In eyes there is no counter current mechanism.

Other options:

Option B: Testes are kept cool by the heat exchange in a countercurrent manner between spermatic arteries and veins as it is necessary for normal spermatogenesis to occur as spermatogenesis occurs at lower temperature than interior of the body.

Option C: Hyperosmolarity of renal medullary interstitium is established by counter current multiplier and urea recycling is maintained by countercurrent exchange in the Vasa recta.

Option D: Counter current mechanism in the villi increases the blood flow in the villi by decreasing oxygen availability for local metabolic reactions of the gut.

Substances and the type of transport across a membrane are given below, choose the correct combination:
questions.solution:
• Oxygen is a nonpolar molecule so transport across a lipid cell membrane through simple diffusion.
  • Glucose transport occurs through facilitated diffusion where no energy is needed but transport proteins like carriers are needed.
  • Glucose transporters move the glucose down its concentration gradients from extracellular fluid (ECF) to cytoplasm of the cell.
  • Voltage gated channels are gated by alterations in membrane potential. Sodium is transported via voltage gated channels which are simple ion channels acting as transport proteins.
  • Active transport requires energy and transport substances against their electrical and chemical gradient so Ca2+ ATPase pumps Ca2+ out of cells.

questions.text: Myosin ceases to be in contact with actin filaments as a result of:
questions.solution:
Myosin ceases to be in contact with actin filaments as a result of attachment of Adenosine triphosphate; (ATP) to myosin head.

Sequence of events of muscle contraction-

  1. At rest, myosin heads are bound to adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and are said to be in a "cocked" position in relation to the thin filament which does not have Ca2+ bound to the troponin-tropomyosin complex.
  2. Following an action potential, cytosolic Ca2+ is increased and free Ca2+ binds to troponin C. Ca2+ bound to the troponin-tropomyosin complex induces a conformational change in the thin filament that allows for myosin heads to cross-bridge with thin filament actin.
  3. Myosin heads rotate, move the attached actin and shorten the muscle fiber, forming the power stroke.
  4. At the end of the power stroke, ATP binds to a new exposed site and causes a detachment from the actin filament.
  5. ATP is hydrolyzed into ADP and inorganic phosphate (Pi) and this chemical energy is used to "re-cock" the myosin head.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

  • Choice A: Dissociation of ADP and Pi
    • The dissociation of ADP and Pi occurs during the power stroke, not during detachment.
    • It strengthens the actin-myosin binding instead of breaking it.
  • Choice B: Cessation of calcium release from sarcoplasm
    • While Ca²+ levels do regulate muscle contraction, its removal does not directly cause myosin to detach.
    • Instead, it leads to tropomyosin re-covering actin binding sites, preventing new cross-bridges.
  • Choice C: Conformational change in Troponin T
    • Troponin T anchors the troponin complex to tropomyosin.
    • The relevant conformational change occurs in Troponin C upon Ca²+ binding, not in Troponin T.
    • This step is involved in cross-bridge formation, not detachment.

Key Takeaway:

Myosin detaches from actin when ATP binds to the myosin head, allowing the cycle of muscle contraction to continue.

questions.text: Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Luminal nonheme iron is mostly present in the Fe3+(ferric) state which is reduced to Fe2+(ferrous) iron by ferrireductase which is transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1(DMT1).

Other options:

Option B:

In duodenal cells, Fe2+ iron follows one of the two pathways either Transport to the blood or storage as mucosal iron. Fe2+ which is destined for the circulation is transported from the cytoplasm across the basolateral enterocyte membrane by ferroportin.

Option A:

In circulation, Fe2+ is oxidised to Fe3+ by iron oxidases hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. Newly absorbed Fe3+ iron binds rapidly to transferrin which delivers iron to red cell progenitors in the marrow.

Option C:

Hepcidin is a small circulating peptide which is synthesized and released from the liver in response to increase in intrahepatic iron level which regulates iron absorption in the duodenum by inhibiting iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferroportin causing it to be endocytosed and degraded.
